captions.text:
It is highly unlikely that the
new Porsche Boxster is

anything other than a brilliant
car to drive.

But we at Drive have a more
important question to ask, and
that is this--

has Porsche finally built a
Boxster that a man can buy?

From the looks alone, you'd have
to say that they've made

a much more desirable car
than the last Boxster.

The wheelbase is 60 millimeters
longer.
The front track is wider.
The rear track is wider.

The overall length is up 32
millimeters, but the front

overhang is 27 millimeters
shorter.

And the upshot of these
undigestible figures is a car

with its wheels pushed further
out riding, in the case of

this Boxster S, 13 millimeters
lower.

Porsche doesn't do radical
interiors.

So the rev counter still lurks
sensibility in the middle of

the clock, and the gear
indicator still looks like it
was designed by a ZX Spectrum.

But the rest is much higher
quality than before.

And while all the surfaces are
covered in optional leather,

it feels and looks
really expensive.

Sadly, the pointless and
irritating Sport Chrono clock

makes a return in this
981 Boxster.
But you can't win them all.

This Boxster S now has swagger,
and shoulders, a big

boot, 315 horsepower, optional
20-inch wheels.

And at 1,320 kilograms,
it weighs 30
kilograms less than before.

But to my eyes, it
just looks right.

But enough about poncy
details down on the
beach in San Tropez.

We want to drive this car
properly 'til we're up in the

hills a long way away from that,
away from civilization.

Let me tell you now, before we
even drive the car, thank you,

Porsche, for launching it in the
best place in the world.

No poncing about, get up, 7:30,
get some keys, head up
towards the Route Napoleon.

These are the best driving
roads in the world.

And I hate to disappoint
everyone that
loves to hate Porsche.

This is another brilliant
sports car.
315 horsepower, as we said.
265 foot-pounds of torque.
A little over 1,300 kilograms.
Do you know what?

You drive the Boxster S with the
six-speed manual gearbox

like this, and you do think
to yourself, what
more car do I need?
Do I need a faster car?
Do I need a more agile car?
Do I need a grippier car?
You just don't.
This thing is brilliant.
Why is it brilliant?

Well, let's start at
the front axle.

We've got a 60 millimeter longer
wheel base, we've also

got 40 millimeters wider axle
width at the front.

This car turns in like
no other Porsche.

The 991 kind of took
the 911 into
Cayman, Boxster territory.

Well, six months later,
Porsche's taken the mid-engine

car into another area
all together.

This car has just got so much
turn-in, so much precision,

that you can drive it
incredibly fast and
accurately.
And it's so composed.

Drive down a road with the
optional PASM suspension in

Comfort, so non-Sport, it
soaks up bumps, it feels
stiff, it feels rigid.

And yet, it's compliant,
you know?

It's a lovely balance of all the
things that you want in a
sports car.

Stiff when you want it to be,
but, you know, a little more

relaxing when you don't want
it to be so harsh.

And what about that
electric steering?

That's the moot point,
isn't it?

Journalists fighting over their
free dinner last night,

saying, oh, I'm not
sure about this.
Well, look.

Here's my thoughts on
electrical steering.

Fundamentally, no,
it's a bad idea.

But it's kind of here to stay
to make sure that cars like

this can be more fuel efficient
and get through
those dreaded emissions tests.

So if it's here to stay, I'm
going to put up with it.
Do I love it?
No, I don't.

Would I single the steering of
the Boxster out as being

something that I would
say was brilliant?
No.

It's the weakest part
of the package.

Is it actively getting in the
way of me having a good time
in this car?
No, it's not.

In summary, it's really
accurate.

I think it's better than the
steering on the 991.

What it does do is it lacks that
kind of pattery, jiggly
conversational feel.

That sounds, I know, like it's
going to end up in "Pseuds
Corner" on Private Eye.
But you get what I mean.

You get into an old Boxster
after this, and the wheel

jiggle and wriggle in a way
that tells you more about
surface conditions.

I have to say, in my experience,
the biggest

problem with electric power
steering is when the road gets
a bit damp.

Because that's when you want
that extra information coming
back at you.

In the drive today, I can put
this car within inches of
where I need it to be.
And that's the way I judge it.

I think it's more than good
enough for the package.

Now the spec of your
Boxster is a bit
complicated to explain.

Optional is PASM, which is the
Porsche Active Suspension
Management.

And also optional is the PTV,
which is Porsche Torque

Vectoring, where you effectively
have one of the

wheels braked on the inside
of the corner.

And that works in conjunction
with a mechanical locking

differential, 22% locking on
drive and 27% on coast.

Now let me just decipher
some of that for you.

Basically, if you've got a
standard Boxster on PASM,

which is what I'm driving,
coming out of some second-gear

corners you can get the inside
wheel spooling up.

I'd love to drive one with the
optional locking diff.

But sadly, couldn't
get one today.

As it stands, it's a really,
really nice suspension package
on the road.

But I've left it in
Comfort all day.

I tried it in Sport mode, and
it just becomes too firm.
You don't need it.

The car's got so much damping
potential and so good at

riding the bumps, why would
you make it go all stiff?
I just wouldn't.

It also has Sport and Sport Plus
buttons, which sharpen
the throttle response.

And if you leave the traction
control and stability on,

Sport Plus and Sport just give
you slightly more slip angle

when you're coming out
of the corner.

If you turn it all off, it will
do some slithery stuff.

But interestingly, when you look
at the big slides we're

doing on the film in a minute--
go on, Neil, put one

in now, yeah-- at the end there,
the light started to

flash even though I turned it
all off, and it straightened
the car again.

So is Porsche now guilty of
having a system you can't
switch off completely?
I hope not.
What about this engine?

New DFI engine, 3.4 liters,
effectively very similar to

the one that's in
the base 991.
It's a cracking motor.
It's responsive.
It's very crisp.

It makes a much better noise
than the last Boxster, to me,
feels more like a 911 noise.

And of course, being
mid-engined, you get the
intakes closer to your head.

They're now dual intake, so
it's not just on one side.

So the passenger gets some
good noise as well.

This thing, with a manual
gearbox, is pretty much five

seconds dead to 62 miles
an hour, and 170 miles
an hour flat out.
Do you need a faster car?
I'm not sure you do.

It lacks a bit of torque coming
out of second-gear
corners sometimes.

I suppose we've only
got six ratios.

But I've just found myself today
thinking, what car do I

need that's more than this
in terms of being
faster and more capable?
I'm not sure I do.

In fact, I'm having a very
sticky moment here because

never since the Boxster
arrived in 1996 have I

preferred the Boxster to
the 911 of the time.

But right now, I'm
very, very close.

To come back to our original
question, does that mean that

I'm having a struggle
with my masculinity?
I'm not quite sure.
Better find out.

Oh, and of course then there's
the six-speed manual gearbox,

not some doctored version
of a seven-speed
PDK with three pedals.

This is a proper six-speed
manual.

And after months of having to
drive flappy paddles, PDKs,

whatever you call them, DSGs,
I just think it's so
refreshing.

I think it brings you closer
into the driving experience.

And that's what a sports
car should be about.

So what, perhaps, you lose in
the steering in the Boxster

you get back with this
proper gearbox.

This, to me, is more important
than the steering.
Oh, one other thing.
The brake pedal, Porsche.

What is it about having the
brake pedal too high relative
to the throttle?
I just don't get it.

Heeling and toeing in this
car is not easy.

And I don't care if only 3% of
potential buyers will actually

roll onto the throttle
when they brake.

Porsche should make cars for
people that care, and these

pedals show some negligence
in that area.

I suppose you could say
that the interior
isn't exactly inspiring.

But actually, in terms of fit,
finish, and trim, like the

991, it's light years beyond
the old Boxster.

This feels like a really,
really high-quality car.

And with a leather-covered dash
in your 40-grand plain

Boxster, that's a hell of a
good-looking, good-feeling car
for the money.

I think it's a complete
bargain.

So what is wrong with
the Boxster, then?

OK, the steering is a slightly
weak link compared to the rest
of the chassis.

Maybe that's because the rest
of it's so damn competent.
It lacks a little bit of feel.

Personally, I do think it's a
shame that a company like

Porsche that makes emotional
sports cars suddenly wants to

slightly filter out some of
that sensation through the
steering rack.
But, you know what?
They've done it.

I'm not going to carp
any more than that.
I really am not.

I think the rest of the
car is just superb.

I do have certain other
problems, I suppose.

This electronic handbrake down
to my left makes me swear

every time I do a three-point
turn or a hill start.

I absolutely hate the
bloody thing.

So dear Porsche, can
you get rid of it
or never do it again?
It's rubbish.

On a practical level, this is
such an easy car to fit into
your different driving moods.

If you want to just roll the
roof down after lunch with

your other half and just go for
a mooch, you feel entirely
comfortable in it.

It's got heated seats, you don't
get buffeted too much.
It's just easy.
It fits in with your life.

But if you want to go a bit
quicker, the moment you want
that response, it's there.

It's a really, really
clever package.

So this is what I think
about the new Boxster.

I think it's an amazing
transformation, actually.

Porsche's taken what was already
a talented sports car

and made it more sporting
and better to drive.

But it's also made the car,
which was already very usable,
even more usable.

So it's just broadened the
appeal of the car that much

further to mean that I don't
think it has a rival in the
marketplace.
Z4, SLK, great cars.
But they're just different.
This is a proper sports car.

Is it a car that a
man could buy?
Absolutely.
Do I prefer it to a 911?

I just don't know
at the moment.
But I've loved this car today.
It looks great on the road.

And I don't feel in any way
self-conscious driving it.
So I think it's a great result.

title: The 2012 Porsche Boxster S - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS

comments.text:
Lovely car! I hate the newly luxurious interior and sharper styling though, 
too much chrome and screens everywhere, and a button for the handbreak... 
my god! I dont think i could bring myself to buy one over the older cars, 
but still its nice that porsche is making a damn good car for those that 
want the tech and handling.

I miss the retro styling that the first boxster had, all the smooth lines 
right off of a 550. Still right-o to Porsche for making while still a 
fairly neutered by tech car, one that is much better than the competition. 
for the time being that is, word is the boxster is loosing two cylinders as 
well as gaining a tubro..... Who gives a shit about speed, the cars quick 
enough, has been since 97.. well maybe the 2000 S model (as quick as the 
new base.) With porsche going turbo, they ought to drop the 911 engines in 
the boxster... just without the turbo, finally set the boxster and cayman 
into place as the enthusiast cars, and the 911 as the car to buy to impress 
your neighbor.﻿

comments.text:
The comment about the useless Sports Chrono on the dash seemed to ignore 
that the Sports Chrono option also gives dynamic transmission mounts on the 
981 series -- making it tighter when G-forces are up.  It improves the 
handling somewhat.  I also think the chronometer on the dash just looks 
cool.  I loved Chris' comments about leaving the PASM in normal mode.  That 
was good feedback to hear about how well the PASM was working, since it's 
active all the time, just to different levels of engagement.﻿

comments.author: abuelT

comments.text:
+Pushkar Sawant other way around...if you want to track the Boxster is 
better. If you're actually racing then the Cayman would offer better 
rollover protection but most Porsches that even see the track are not there 
to race. The Boxster has no weight at all on top, thus it has more grip at 
every corner. This allows for more options to on selecting the racing line 
that offers the most grip---> fastest lap. 
The Cayman is more rigid but contrary to popular misconception it is not a 
net benefit as the platform was designed not to have a roof from inception. 
Which is why the GT4 has a bespoke body shell that none of the other 
Caymans have, to reduce the weight on top penalty without sacrificing 
safety. Additionally the Caymans R and the new GT4 both require a rear 
spoiler to keep up with the Spyders that can be quick with just a duck 
tail. If we in fact see a Spyder GT4 it will be faster than the Cayman GT4 
if all other things remain equal. If we were talking about Cabriolet where 
the roof was hacked off like on the 911, then the coupe would be quicker.
comments.author: porscheoscar

comments.text:
+analanalyst the torsional rigidity has been reduced to a seriously low 
level. Out of your mind.....what are you talking about ...one is a soft the 
other is a box on wheels.
comments.author: Johhny England

comments.text:
That's like asking, "what is better? Candy or ice cream?"
Look it all comes down to what YOU are looking to buy. 
That's basically why they are two different cars.
One is a soft roof convertible.
The other is a coupe.
Yes, they are basically based on the same car but they serve two different 
sectors of the market.
If you want to go to the track and race your car, obviously the Cayman.
But if you already have owned a coupe and would like to buy a convertible 
just to see how it is like owning one, then the Boxster maybe?

comments.text:
For that statement to be anything more than an echo of something you heard 
somebody say about Boxster, you need to say exactly what is "girly" about 
it ... not phallic enough in profile? Too busty? Too fluffy? Is it the 
canopy bed-ness of it or the apple-tini-like sweetness?

And "girls like roadsters?" Like Steve McQueen's XKSS Jag? Stereotypes like 
that are for people who are too lazy to think. They hear or read them a 
couple of times and then repeat ... girl's car, girl's car .... mustn't 
like that, or my masculinity is in question. By all means, buy the car that 
suits your self image (if you can afford it) - most of us will. But get 
over that idea that what anyone else is driving has anything to do with 
what YOU think of the car.

comments.text: How much on average does it cost to maintain a boxster s?﻿
comments.author: Thomas Xie

comments.text:
+anexplosionbam You must live in an expensive place. I paid less than $200 
at my local dealer for the 10k oil change and about $400 for the 20k 
service that includes an oil change. The more expensive parts are: new 
tires after 12k to 20k miles. My PZeros made it about 18k miles). After ca 
25k to 35k miles new brake pads you can find online for $250 to $300 
(texcel) or $700 (pagid rs 29 which are track brakes) plus installation (ca 
2 to 3 hours). At some points (I expect at around 35k to 40k based on my 
usage pattern) probably new brake front discs and again a new set of tires.
comments.author: Mike981S

comments.text:
+porscheoscar right on. Ive had the car, and any part i have replaced has 
came with a 996 part number, the cars are very very alike, just with 
different driving dynamics. Same engine, same chassis mostly, same steering 
breakes etc. Fixing things isnt that bad, bought a MAF today for 277 USD, 
AOS, Waterpump, Fuel pump, and a few other little things are common 
problems, but overall they are affordable to maintain, and a great joy. Ive 
driven 911s, and its just not quite right. The 911 is great if you want a 
bit more power, but if you know how to use it you can be quite a bit 
quicker in a mid engine chassis.
comments.author: TheBIGJake111

comments.text:
+Thomas Xie The same it costs to maintain a 911 from the same year. From 
1996 through 2004 the Boxster was a Carrera from the rear doors to the 
front of the car. The engine has the same design the only real difference 
is that it was deliberately made with less power. But since the Boxster is 
shorter and lighter, having the same amount of power would make the Boxster 
quicker since it has lower center of gravity and mid engine handling.
comments.author: porscheoscar

comments.text:
He probably meant 1st time is only an oil change and yes it does cost about 
$300-400 at dealer. 2nd time mayb at 20k service so it does cost a lil more 
since require some air filters. 3rd time 30k interval, dealer probably 
gonna charge an arm and leg for some flush fluid, oil change, filters 
etc... so it'll cost even more. But with new technology and now aday new 
car doesnt need anything but oil change atleast till 50k+ for any minor 
services.
